text: Heyya! I'm Rainer. I'm from all over :earth_africa: but currently in Sierra Leone :flag-sl: I found you by going down the "What happened to Eve?" google-path. I would like to build a literate programming app centered around a journal / research log that's always just a keystroke away and tracks my activities to document my thought process (will probably be tightly integrated into the OS). I'm also super interested in learning / Spaced Repetition (especially enumerating "requirements/dependencies" for any lesson, to find a shortest path to a new piece of knowledge.) I'll probably just lurk here for a while, but will hopefully have some prototypes to show you some day.

text:
Hey folks, I'm Jeremy. I'm based in Ottawa, ON, Canada. Been listening to the podcast off and on for a while, don't remember how I found it.
I've been programming since I was 4 years old using BASIC on a Commodore Vic-20. My career as a developer has been kind of all over the map, but the relevant detail for this crowd is that I got very excited about DSLs in the early 2000s and went to work at Intentional Software for five and a half years (2006-2011).
I also run a game-making community at <http://glorioustrainwrecks.com|glorioustrainwrecks.com>, where the guiding ethos is to be creative and expressive without gatekeeping or judgement about your choice of tools, game mechanics, or subject matter. Tiny, weird, and personal games are the norm, to the extent there is a norm. Hyper-accessible game-making tools like Klik & Play and Twine deserve to be talked about in the same breath as Hypercard IMO.
In general, my main interest at this point is empowering ordinary people; computing should be understandable, accessible, personal, collaborative, and in the direct control of the people who use it. When I was a kid, I was surrounded by tools that were designed to be learnable by people who had never touched a keyboard, and resources that encouraged me that understanding computers was not only possible, but fun and rewarding. To the extent that improving programming can advance that goal, I am on board.

To the extent that improving programming can advance that goal, I am on board.

text: I'm excited to meet someone who worked at Intentional Software! I've watched videos of Charles Simonyi talk about links in code being stored as strong references, and about generative programming. I don't think think those concepts are foreign to this community, but I was very excited to see a real company (Intentional) formed around doing programming that way. I look forward to whatever insights you can find and provide in this community.

elements.text: I'm excited to meet someone who worked at Intentional Software! I've watched videos of Charles Simonyi talk about links in code being stored as strong references, and about generative programming. I don't think think those concepts are foreign to this community, but I was very excited to see a real company (Intentional) formed around doing programming that way. I look forward to whatever insights you can find and provide in this community.

text: I really hope that someday some artifact of all that work makes it out of Microsoft! It's very frustrating to me that it's never been made available to the public at all.

elements.text: I really hope that someday some artifact of all that work makes it out of Microsoft! It's very frustrating to me that it's never been made available to the public at all.

text: Can you give us a big picture description of the type of projects inside Intentional <@UHPAERALD>

elements.text: Can you give us a big picture description of the type of projects inside Intentional

text:
The main project while I was there was a general-purpose structured editor called the Intentional Domain Workbench. You defined a schema for your language, we gave you an IDE, which you could progressively enhance with custom notations and functionality.
_Everything_ in the system was built around tree transformations - the entire editor was a series of compiler passes from domain code to an editor language to a layout language to a graphics language - and all transformations had rich mappings between their input and output, so you could connect a pixel on the screen back to its source. 
I spent most of my time working on persistence and version control - merging of trees based on full edit history, unobtrusively modelling conflicts, etc. 
We had a couple of pilot customers that we built workbenches for, to prove out the approach - iirc we demoed one based around administrating pensions a few times. There are screenshots for sure, not sure if there's video.

elements.text: The main project while I was there was a general-purpose structured editor called the Intentional Domain Workbench. You defined a schema for your language, we gave you an IDE, which you could progressively enhance with custom notations and functionality.

I spent most of my time working on persistence and version control - merging of trees based on full edit history, unobtrusively modelling conflicts, etc. 
We had a couple of pilot customers that we built workbenches for, to prove out the approach - iirc we demoed one based around administrating pensions a few times. There are screenshots for sure, not sure if there's video.

text: It sounds similar to Jetbrains MPS. If you are familiar with it, can you explain how it's the same or different?

elements.text: It sounds similar to Jetbrains MPS. If you are familiar with it, can you explain how it's the same or different?

text: Version control (and merging and comparing) of trees (versus pain text) would be invaluable to what many of us are trying to do. I'd be interested in learning more about that. Is that something that might ever become available? (As a separate tool, or as part of IDW?)
